laboratory_examinations.findings: Elevated T levels ranged from 54–138 ng/dl (1.9–4.8 nmol/liter); normal range <130 ng/dl (1.0 nmol/liter).
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: At age 3 years, T levels were 178 ng/dl (6.2 nmol/liter) and did not increase after acute ACTH stimulation. After steroid therapy, T levels decreased to normal prepubertal levels and remained within the prepubertal range over 24 months.

laboratory_examinations.findings: Serum basal cortisol and aldosterone levels were very low and did not rise after ACTH stimulation (Cosyntropin, 250 μg).
Extremely elevated at 5016 pg/ml (1104.5 pmol/liter); normal range <160 pg/ml (13.3 pmol/liter).
Elevated PRA at 7.3 ng/ml; normal range 0.9–1.9 ng/ml.
Compatible with a prepubertal pattern with low LH levels.
Bone age was 6 years when chronological age was 2 years and 5 months.
laboratory_examinations.changes_over_time: A recent assessment showed a bone age of 7 years at a chronological age of 5 years.
